messages: e177a053e6927b9e8d443b8e2fee10e0 (23:24): Does 4.2 bring SVG improvements?  If so, please mention it on svg.org
e177a053e6927b9e8d443b8e2fee10e0 (23:28): if that's too much work, please mention it on #svg
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:30): hm, does it?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:31): No, in fact to my knowledge it doesn't even support ALL of the SVG standard.
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:31): hm, the font that QGraphicsSimpleTextItem uses isn't "normal", it's an outline font
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:31): chakie: I mentioned that. ;)
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:31): no, it supports the "tiny" thingie
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:31): chakie: Renders into a path, renders the path.
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:32): ahigerd: i didn't understand it until i set a huge font
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:32): kinda stupid
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:32): Did something unusual happen when you scaled it up that high?
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:32): well, not "huge", 24pt
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:32): Ah.
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:33): 48pt looks kinda nice
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:33): but it's not practical :)
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:34): nah, scaling it looks really bad
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:35): it's still an outline that gets scaled, and when it's scaled to my "normal" small size it's a mess

e177a053e6927b9e8d443b8e2fee10e0 (23:35): ahigerd, "support ALL of SVG"? If you mean SVG 1.1 Full, which viewer does? Even HTML+CSS is usually not perfectly supported yet. SVG developments go fast nowadays
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:36): Hehe
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:37): http://www.smultron.net/tmp/font.png
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:38): i think i could render my text into a QPixmap and then use a QGraphicsPixmapItem to display it
e8d02d72bee77f86138ae3caa93f5e4b (23:38): i think i should report a bug about this, it worked right in rc1
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (23:52): I'm building someone else's qt4 project. There are .pro files. What do I put in the .pro files to make it build a static binary?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:54): CONFIG += static, but you also have to have a statically-built Qt library.
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (23:55): ahigerd: I'll check into that. Thanks.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:57): I keep two copies of Qt around -- one dynamic, one static -- and I call the qmake binary for the appropriate version when I need it.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (23:57): (The Windows installer comes with both sets of libraries already built.)
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:05): LUG was fun
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:06): like that guys even if they dont have a clue what a console is
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:07): XD
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:09): ahigerd: what is a BYTE again? sory i forgot it
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (00:10): aep: It's two nybbles. I mean, duh.
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:11): 2nibbles are one byte, indeed
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:12): that dosnt help much though ;)
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (00:12): Google for it. A hex digit (i.e. four bits) is sometimes referred to as a nibble (or nybble).
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:12): sorry i wasnt very verbose
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:13): aep: Think of it as quint8
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:13): i need to know what the type BYTE declairs in windows
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:13): ahigerd: thanks
92a5653ef0a74265fb40402cdc70d697 (00:13): Sorry for interrupting: on Windows is it necessary to do configure and make or pre-built Qt will work fine?
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (00:13): aep: Oh, I thought you were making fun of the Linux newbies. My mistake.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:14): Hehe, nah, stupid Windows typedefs. :P
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:14): Eldarin: Pre-built works if you don't need SQL
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:14): Eldarin: the binary packages work fine with mingw
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (00:14): Eldarin: The libraries you link to must have been compiled by the same compiler that you will be using to build your apps.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:14): Point, that does assume you're using MinGW
92a5653ef0a74265fb40402cdc70d697 (00:15): I see... I'll try to do it with MinGW...
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:15): Of course, if you're not a commercial customer, using it with Visual Studio is a hack anyway ;)
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:15): And I don't even think it builds on Cygwin at all
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (00:16): Could be wrong.
92a5653ef0a74265fb40402cdc70d697 (00:16): Can two copies of Qt be installed on Windows at the same time?
92a5653ef0a74265fb40402cdc70d697 (00:17): One configured and made works fine... Will installing another one to test compilation confuse the system? :)
099bbfab0c29724b260374e1d4238ca3 (00:17): ahigerd: I think you have to use the X11 version with cygwin. Not 100% sure.
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:18): Eldarin: yes you may have multiple qt installs
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:18): just give every install its own dir
92a5653ef0a74265fb40402cdc70d697 (00:18): Thanx for help! Good night!
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:24): BYTE *pfad = reinterpret_cast<BYTE *> (QString(QDir::homePath ()+"\\sysmon\\sysmon.exe").toUtf8().data());
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:24): anything wrong with that?
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:26): (ignore the QString ctor abuse ;)
1f00490ca8bb9114a78573d2b8a21836 (00:27): aep: toUtf8() returns a QByteArray
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:28): thats what i expect to do it ;)
1f00490ca8bb9114a78573d2b8a21836 (00:28): if you don't assign it anywhere, the compiler will destruct it after executing the rest of your statement
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:28): and QByteArray.data(9 reuturns a char *
1f00490ca8bb9114a78573d2b8a21836 (00:28): meaning, you're getting a pointer to recently freed memory
1f00490ca8bb9114a78573d2b8a21836 (00:28): (i've been bit by that before)
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:32): QByteArray bla = QString(QDir::homePath ()+"\\sysmon.exe").toUtf8();
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:32): BYTE *pfad = reinterpret_cast<BYTE *> (bla.data());
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:32): still dosnt work

86ec5627dfe80cac1a06bc97c23bb800 (00:40): hm what is the fastest way to display a large image in a QScrollArea? it could be several times larger than the view, and i need to edit this images pixel data
86ec5627dfe80cac1a06bc97c23bb800 (00:41): i have a qlabel with a qpixmap now, and copying a qimage into the pixmap, but i dunno..
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:49): you may either put the qlabel into the scroollarea, iherit the scrollarea, or use qimage
86ec5627dfe80cac1a06bc97c23bb800 (00:53): the qlabel with a qpixmap is already inside the scrollarea.  any faster way to get the qimage to show in the scrollarea than copying it into the qpixmap?
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:54): paint it directly
021b7bf3ff2076c746a1ed6f90658a06 (00:54): dunno if tahst much faster
